repnme.cdata!:
Jordan - Second Economic Reform and
            Development Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Economic Reform
            and Development Loan Project in Jordan are as follows:
            overall outcome of the project was rated highly
            satisfactory, and the performance of the Bank and the
            Borrower were rated satisfactory. The success of this
            operation provides a good example of close collaboration
            with the borrower during the design and implementation
            phases. The program design was made comprehensive enough for
            the government to adopt it as its own medium-term
            development agenda which could also be used in addressing
            the concerns of a number of other key development partners
            of Jordan. Since the reform program had been implicitly
            endorsed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), the
            European Community and other major donors, its justification
            and rationalization were no longer the issues to be resolved.

Jordan - Second Economic Reform and

5082982.majtheme: Public sector governance,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Jordan - Second Economic Reform and
            Development Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
An important policy direction supported
            by the Second Economic Reform and Development Loan (ERDL-II)
            is the removal of remaining trade and investment barriers,
            paving the way for higher economic growth and export
            earnings, a closer trade relation with the European Union
            and accession to the World Trade Organization.  Further
            objectives are: to broaden and deepen financial
            intermediation, to provide an enabling business environment
            and increase the private sector's economy share.
            Furthermore, the loan will provide Jordan with short-term
            balance of payments support in order to strengthen its
            international reserves position.  The ERDL-II supports trade
            and investment policy reforms to: a) further reduce
            anti-export bias, to foster integration with world market,
            and reduce administrative obstacles; b) improve banking
            competition and the efficiency of financial intermediation;
            c) improve viability of financial institutions and eliminate
            special privileges; d) encourage long-term saving and
            promote development of new financial instruments and
            markets; e) encourage entry, improve incentives, and offer
            national treatment to foreign investors; f) modernize a
            broad range of business laws; and g) improve opportunities
            for private sector firms, increase competition, allow the
            Government to concentrate on its core functions, and achieve
            greater efficiency through privatization and restructuring.

Jordan - Second Economic Reform and
